name: Seeds of Expression
description:
How can knowledge be passed down through a seed?

Join Arunkumar HG and Dayananda Nagaraju, exhibiting artists of CALORIE, as they explore their exhibits in detail.

Learn about the Akshatha Seedbank with Arunkumar as he shares how it became the foundation of the exhibit Vulnerable Guardians. Discover how this collection of seeds is a living archive of resilience, biodiversity, and cultural memory. Arunkumar will further dive into the ties between farmers, landscapes and seeds, while reflecting on how a seedbank can be a container of knowledge and wisdom from those who came before.

Dayananda will reflect on the artistic process behind his exhibit, Atantraru & The Golden Seed. He reflects on how a thought begins like a seed—small, invisible, and full of potential—and how it finds its way into expression through his artistic practice. Dayananda explores the ecology of creativity, the conditions that allow ideas to germinate, the fragility and resilience of expression, and the collective fields in which thoughts grow. Come and learn how an artwork - just like a seed - can carry memory and possibility!

name: Tales of Ragi
description:
What can we learn from a simple Ragi plant?

Join artist Surekha as she shares her experience of making ‘ragi.net’ - an exhibit displayed as part of CALORIE - through an interactive workshop. Participants will be invited to share their stories about Ragi in the urban context to uncover the lived and historic stories and experience of ragi, its journey between the rural and the urban contexts. Subramani, an artist from the farming community, will also join the workshop and share his experience of being both a farmer and artist, through his drawings and lived experiences. Explore the entire cycle of ragi, from seed to a fully grown plant, extracted and consumed.

name: Eat, Read, Think
description:
Eat, Read, Think is a reading circle run by Science Gallery Bengaluru, bringing together curious minds to explore ideas through literature and conversation. Readings will be themed around the current exhibition season, CALORIE, exploring humanity's fraught and intimate relationship with food through readings inspired by the many exhibits present throughout the gallery. Eat, Read, Think welcomes young people from all walks of life to gather for conversations that connect science, culture and society.

For the reading circle's second meetup we will look at P. Sainaths’s article “Agriculture in the age of inequality”. 

Come for community stay for snacks!

name: Public Engagement and Health: Data, Dialogue and Action
description:
What does meaningful engagement around public health look like in practice? 

In an era of widening health inequities, fast‑moving technology and shrinking public trust, what can outcomes look like? Public engagement is not just about delivering health messages or translating science; it's about sharing power, building trust, and co-creating solutions that reflect lived realities.

Join Ashata Dahal, Pattie Gonsalves and Tasha Koch in a panel discussion as they unpack how decisions are made in today’s landscape of health.

name: A Bite of CALORIE: Kannada Walkthrough
description: Join the Science Gallery Bengaluru team for a closer look at our new exhibition season, CALORIE, one bite at a time. This walkthrough, conducted in Kannada, invites you to reflect on the ideas of food, nutrition, and energy. As we move through the exhibition, the team will unpack the intimate, and often complicated, relationships we share with food, nourishment, and the systems that sustain us.

name: Forbidden Desire: Sugar Blowing Workshop
description:
Sugar is a material full of contrasts, a sweet delight and a forbidden indulgence. Inspired by artist Jade Armstrong’s original concept, this workshop explores the delicate balance between beauty, sweetness, and the fleeting nature of life.

In this workshop, Chef Pratyay will guide the participants to learn and to create intricate sugar-blown sculptures, each capturing a single breath and symbolising both the passage of time and the fragility of life. As these sculptures slowly melt into syrupy residue, they reflect sugar’s transformation from a prized luxury to an overconsumed treat.

This hands-on experience encourages reflection on desire, decay, and consumption.
